Scheme 1 A plausible mechanism of CuSe2-catalyzed reductive carbonylation of nitroarene to produce urethane. The solid box explains about the enhanced urethane productivity when adding corresponding amino compound to the nitro compound-based main catalytic cycle. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 X-ray diffraction spectra (XRD) of (a) CuxSey and (b) standard spectra of Krutaite CuSe2. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of CuSe2 in the region of (a) Cu 2p and (b) Se 3d, and (c) C 1s. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of (a–b) CuSe2 synthesized without CTAB; (c–d) CuSe2 synthesized with CTAB; (e–f) CuSe2/CeO2 synthesized without CTAB; (g–h) CuSe2/CeO2 synthesized with CTAB. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Product compositional changes as a function of time in the reductive carbonylation of NB in the presence of CuSe2/CeO2. Conditions: NB (10 mmol), 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2 (1 g, [CuSe2]: 0.225 mmol), molar ratio of NB/CuSe2 = 44, T =160 °C, P =8.3 MPa of CO. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Effect of temperature on the formation of MPC in the presence of CuSe2/CeO2. Conditions: NB (10 mmol), 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2 (1 g, [CuSe2]: 0.225 mmol), molar ratio of NB/CuSe2 = 44, P =8.3 MPa of CO, t =4 h. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effect of CO pressure on the formation of MPC in the presence of CuSe2/CeO2. Conditions: NB (10 mmol), 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2 (1 g, [CuSe2]: 0.225 mmol), molar ratio of NB/CuSe2 = 44, T =160 °C, t =4 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effect of the addition of aniline on the activity of the reductive carbonylation of nitrobenzene. Conditions: NB (10 mmol), 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2 (1 g, [CuSe2]: 0.225 mmol), molar ratio of NB/CuSe2 = 44, T =160 °C, P =8.3 MPa of CO, t =4 h. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Catalyst recyclability in the reductive carbonylation of NB at 140 °C, 8.3 MPa of CO for 4 h in the presence of 2 g of 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 X-ray diffraction spectra of (a) fresh catalyst CuSe2, (b) recovered CuSe2 after 4th recycling in the reductive carbonylation reaction of NB. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 FT-IR spectra of (a) CuSe2 obtained from the reaction with CO, (b) CuSe2 obtained from the reaction with CO/O2 gas mixture (v/v = 80:20), (c) CuSe2 obtained from the reaction with CO by adding NB as oxidant, and (d) spent CuSe2 after the carbonylation. Graphical abstract A cheap and effective heterogeneous catalyst, CuSe2/CeO2 is developed for the reductive carbonylation of nitroarenes for generating corresponding urethanes. A reaction mechanism using this recyclable catalyst is presented, especially invoking the importance of CuSe2(μ-CO) species. The advantageous features of using this CuSe2/CeO2 catalyst includes that non-expensive and easy-to-prepare, which can be applied to the reductive carbonylation of various nitroarenes that had to employ precious noble metals such as Pd, Rh, and Ru. The reaction of CuCl2, SeO2, and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) under the CO pressure in methanol produce a black solid, which is identified as cupric diselenide, CuIISe2 using various spectroscopic analyses. Impregnation of 5 wt% of CuSe2 onto CeO2 resulted in much more enhanced catalytic activity due to the uniform and highly dispersed particle. The reductive carbonylation of nitrobenzene (NB) as a model substrate has been examined in the presence of the CuSe2/CeO2 as a single component heterogeneous catalyst, which is found to exhibit excellent catalytic activity for generating methyl-N-phenyl carbamate (MPC) in a highly selective fashion. The effects of various reaction parameters such as temperature, pressure, and reaction time have been investigated. A plausible reaction mechanism using this cheap heterogeneous catalyst is also presented, especially invoking the importance of CuSe2(μ-CO) species. Keywords Cupric diselenide Nitrobenzene Reductive carbonylation Urethane Carbamate 1 Introduction Carbamates are regarded as important precursors for preparing isocyanates, a key monomer for polyurethane, since the carbamates can be transformed into isocyanates and alcohols by thermal cracking. Carbamates have been commercially produced by reacting phosgene with corresponding amines, which has fatal drawbacks such as difficulties in removing corrosive hydrogen chloride as a secondary product as well as the use of intrinsic toxic phosgene as a reactant. Accordingly, there have been tremendous efforts for the synthesis of carbamates via non-phosgene protocol [1–8]. One of the promising approaches is the catalytic reductive carbonylation of nitroarenes with carbon monoxide in the presence of alcohol and a proper catalyst. Several effective catalyst systems have been reported for preparing carbamates via reductive carbonylation of nitroarenes [9–19]. Group 8–10 noble metals such as Ru, Rh, and Pd or their compounds are commonly used catalysts for this purpose [13,16,20–31]. Among them, notably, Ragaini et al. reported that [Pd(phen)2][BF4]2 delivered methyl-N-phenyl carbamate (MPC) in 81.2% conversion with 87.5% selectivity, corresponding to a turnover frequency (TOF) of almost 6000 h−1, which is the highest record until now [9]. Although remarkable, these metals above have some negative aspects concerning the industrial viewpoint, i.e., i) poor catalyst recovery due to the homogeneous system, and ii) hurdle to catalyst modulation and recycling of expensive noble metals. Selenium or selenium compounds are also known to convert aliphatic and aromatic amines to the corresponding carbamates in high yield via reductive or oxidative carbonylation depending on the oxidation state of selenium species. In the case of oxidative carbonylation of aromatic amines, the main active species is known as SeIV such as SeO2, M2Se2O5, MSeO3, MSeO2(OR), and QSeO2(OR) (M = alkali metal; Q = imidazolium, phosphonium) [1,2,32] whereas it is Se(0) in the case of reductive carbonylation [33–37]. During the course of our study on the various catalyst combinations comprising selenium-based and other metal halides for the reductive carbonylation of nitrobenzene (NB) as a model substrate to produce MPC, a heterogeneous CuIISe2 was found to be made during the reductive carbonylation of NB. As aforementioned, it has been known that only Se(0) is able to catalyze NB to produce carbamates and/or disubstituted ureas via reductive carbonylation protocol, however, it is only effective in aliphatic amines [34,38]. As far as the authors concerned, it would be the first time to report that Se2 2− (Se-) can catalyze nitroarenes to generate mono- and di-urethanes very efficiently in the CuSe2-catalyzed reductive carbonylation. Unlike the Pd-based catalyst, the CuSe2 is a unique heterogeneous catalyst that provides easy catalyst separation as well as extremely high selectivity to carbamates. Moreover, it can be synthesized from 1st transition metal and main group element, leading to a good way to escape from using precious noble metals in the reductive carbonylation nitroarenes. Herein, we report the synthesis and characterization of CuSe2 and supported system, CuSe2/CeO2, as well as its catalytic activity for the reductive carbonylation of nitroarenes for generating urethanes (carbamates) (Eq. 1). Furthermore, a plausible reaction mechanism is proposed using this heterogeneous catalyst system, specifically invoking the importance of CuSe2(μ-CO) species. (1) ArN O 2 +MeOH+3CO ⟶ 5wt % CuS e 2 /Ce O 2 T,P,t ArNHC = O OMe+2C O 2 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals including copper(II) chloride (CuCl2, reagent grade 97%), selenium dioxide (SeO2, reagent grade powder 98.0%), nitrobenzene (ACS reagent ≥ 99.0%), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, > 99.0%), cerium(IV) oxide (CeO2, powder, < 5 μm, 99.9%), γ-Al2O3 (99.97% metals basis, 110 μm powder, S.A. 60 m2/g), and charcoal (activated, untreated, granular, 8–20 mesh) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Nitrobenzene (NB) and methanol were freshly distilled using appropriate drying agent under N2 atmosphere before use. Carbon monoxide (CO) with 99.95% purity was purchased from Uniongas in Korea and used as received. 2.2 Instrumentation The morphology of 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2 was investigated using scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM-6701 F) and transmission electron microscope [TEM, JEM-2100 F (UHR)]. The associated EDX/EDS system (JEOL-Model INCA) was used for analyzing elemental compositions. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was studied to characterize the surface composition and oxidation states of elements at the surface of catalysts using Thermo Fisher instrument equipped with Al K-α radiation source (energy range from 100 eV to 3k eV). In order to study the crystal structure and purity of the CuSe2 and its loading on support, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out using Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation. FT-IR spectra were recorded using Nicolet FT-IR spectrometer. 2.3 Catalysts preparation 2.3.1 Synthesis of cupric diselenide (CuSe2) A mixture of CuCl2 (1.0 g, 7.4 mmol), SeO2 (3.3 g, 29.7 mmol), and CTAB (1.0 g, 2.7 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of H2O. The mixture was then transferred into the glass lined stainless steel autoclave reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer, a thermocouple, and an electric heater. Before the reaction, the reactor was purged 3 times with CO to remove remaining air. The reactor was filled with 2.5 MPa of CO at room temperature and then heated to the desired temperature with vigorous stirring. The reactor was further pressurized to 8.3 MPa at the 160 °C and then maintained constant throughout the reaction using a gas reservoir equipped with a high-pressure regulator and a pressure transducer. After a reaction period of 1 h, the suspension was neutralized using NaOH solution (0.05 M, 5 mL) and the liquid was removed by filtration using cannula filter, and the remaining solid precipitates were washed with distilled water (20 mL) 5 times. The resulting solid (CuSe2) were soxhleted in methanol for 6 h and dried under reduced pressure for 12 h. The prepared CuSe2 was ground in the mortar to make fine powder before use. 2.3.2 Synthesis of 5 wt% CuSe2 supported on CeO2 (CuSe2/CeO2) The CeO2 was dried in the oven at 110 °C for 5 h prior to use. The synthesis of CuSe2/CeO2 was carried out using a similar procedure for preparing CuSe2 except for adding 3.1 g of CeO2 into the water solution containing CuCl2, SeO2, and CTAB. The liquid mixture was stirred for 30 min before transferring into the glass liner of the stainless steel autoclave reactor. 2.4 Carbonylation reaction All experiments were conducted in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer, a thermocouple, and an electric heater. The reactor was loaded with NB and a catalyst. The reactor was pressurized to 2.5 MPa of CO at room temperature and then heated to the desired temperature with vigorous stirring. The reactor was pressurized to 8.3 MPa at 160 °C and then maintained constant throughout the reaction using a gas reservoir equipped with a high-pressure regulator and a pressure transducer. After 4 h reaction, the reactor was cool down to room temperature. Liquid products obtained from the carbonylation reaction were quantified using an Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a HP-5 capillary column and FID detector and heptane was used as an external standard. To ensure the identification of products, GC–MS (Agilent 6890 N-5975 MSD GC-Mass spectrometer) and 1H NMR, 13C NMR (300 MHz Bruker NMR spectrometer) analyses were used. 2.5 FT-IR studies of carbonyl selenide 2.5.1 Using O2 as an oxidant CO chemisorption experiment was carried out in the presence of CO/O2 gas mixture (v/v = 80:20) as an oxidant. The experiment was conducted by reacting 0.1 g of CuSe2 with 3.4 MPa of CO/O2 gas mixture (v/v = 80/20) in the presence of 30 mL of methanol in a stainless steel reactor at 100 °C for 4 h. After completion of the reaction, the solid was collected by filtration and dried under reduced pressure for 12 h. The obtained solid was pelletized with KBr and analyzed by FT-IR spectroscopy. The same procedure was also applied to CuSe2/CeO2 and Se(0) metal for CO chemisorption. 2.5.2 Using nitrobenzene as an oxidant CO chemisorption experiment was conducted with the presence of nitrobenzene as an oxidant. 0.1 g of CuSe2 was reacted with 8.3 MPa of CO pressure in a stainless steel autoclave reactor with the presence of 1 equivalent NB to CuSe2 in 30 mL of methanol at 100 °C for 4 h. After completion of the reaction, the solid was collected by filtration and dried under reduced pressure for 12 h. The obtained solid was pelletized with KBr and analyzed by FT-IR spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activities of various catalyst systems The synthesis of the methyl-N-phenyl carbamate (MPC) from reductive carbonylation of nitrobenzene (NB) was investigated in the presence of a catalyst system comprising three-component, CuCl2, SeO2, and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) in methanol as reactant and solvent. As shown in Table 1 , this catalyst system selectively produces MPC in an excellent yield of 97.5% at 100% conversion of NB. It is interesting to note that the reaction is only effective when all three of CuCl2, SeO2, and CTAB are employed simultaneously. Removing one of the components results in reduced activities (entry 2∼4). As expected, the single component system shows even worse results (entry 5∼7). However, SeO2 as a sole catalyst system affords 25.8% (entry 6), [SeO2 + CTAB] delivers 27.4% (entry 3), and [CuCl2 + SeO2] produces 68.0% of MPC yield (entry 2), indicating that the existence of selenium is playing a certain role in catalyzing the reductive carbonylation. Indeed, Se (0), known catalyst for reductive carbonylation of NB produces 50.3% (entry 8) [60]. Accordingly, the result of 25.8% MPC yield from SeO2 might be resulting from a partial reduction of SeO2 to Se (0) during the reducing environment of the reductive carbonylation [34,37]. As mentioned earlier, the three-component system produced the highest yield of MPC (97.5%). One common phenomenon observed in the reductive carbonylation of NB with the three-component catalyst system is the generation of insoluble black precipitates. Being motivated by this result, in the absence of NB, a reaction is carried out by reacting CuCl2 and SeO2 in the presence of methanolic CTAB solution under the of 8.3 MPa of CO pressure at 160 °C for 4 h, which is the same condition with reductive carbonylation of NB. After completion of the reaction, the liquid phase was removed by filtration, and the remaining solid precipitates were washed with methanol several times, dried under vacuum to give a black solid. Since the FT-IR spectrum of the black solid did not show any organic moiety, it is assumed to be a solid inorganic compound, and it was denoted as CuxSey. 3.2 Catalyst characterization To have a better understanding of CuxSey, XRD analysis on the black solid was carried out. As shown in Fig. 1 , the XRD pattern of CuxSey is well matched with CuSe2 in Krutaite phase structure [JCPDS 26-1115, Table S- 1] [39,40]. EDX/EDS spectra of this solid sample also show that only Cu and Se are observed, and the atomic ratio of Se/Cu is found to be around 2 (Supporting Information, Fig. S-1). To investigate the oxidation state of Cu and Se element in CuSe2, XPS analysis was carried out (Supporting Information, Fig. S-3). The results of XPS survey spectra of CuSe2 show that it consists of only copper and selenium. When we have a close look at the Cu region described in Fig. 2 a, the two peaks of Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 at 932.11 and 952.01 eV clearly indicate the existence of Cu2+, which is well consistent with the literature [39,41–43]. The peak at 54.63 eV in Fig. 2b is ascribed to Se 3d5/2, indicating the existence of Se2 2− species in the CuSe2 [39,42–44]. To investigate the possible formation of carbonaceous species on the catalyst, the C 1s XPS spectrum was considered. Accordingly, Fig. 2c shows only one peak at 284.8 eV, designated as the standard carbon generally used for XPS calibration, indicating that there are no peaks relating to carbonaceous contamination on the surface of the CuSe2. From these spectroscopic data, it is clear that the black solid obtained from the reductive carbonylation is a cupric diselenide (CuIISe2). The formation of CuSe2 has two possible pathways, one from in the presence of methanol (Eq. 2). If we propose another pathway using water as a solvent as presented in Eq. (3), the rate of CuSe2 formation would be facilitated due to the better proton donor ability of water than alcohol for the formation of HCl. Indeed, 1 h reaction was very enough when the CuSe2 was prepared in water, whereas it took 4 h in methanol until it becomes black solids. (2) CuCl2 + 4 SeO2 + 7 CO + CH 3 OH → 2 CuSe2 + 4 HCl + 8 CO2 (3) CuCl2 + 2 SeO2 + 5 CO + H 2 O → CuSe2 + 2 HCl + 5 CO2 3.3 Catalytic activity of CuSe2 and its supported system CuIISe2 (cupric diselenide) prepared from the reaction of CuCl2, SeO2, and CTAB in water as solvent under 8.3 MPa of CO pressure at 160 °C for 1 h was used as a heterogeneous catalyst in the reductive carbonylation of NB. As shown in Table 2 , CuIISe2 shows the highest activity to give 97.5% of MPC yield at 100% NB conversion (entry 1). The only by-product from this reaction was aniline (AN, about 2.5%) which has been recognized as an intermediate in the reductive carbonylation of NB. When the same reaction is carried out using a cupric diselenide prepared without adding CTAB, the yield of MPC decreased to 82.4%, indicating that the existence of surfactant plays a significant role in rendering probably the particle size of the catalyst uniform and small (entry 2). To study the catalytic activity of Se2− species, a commercial grade of CuI 2Se and CuIISe were tested as a catalyst in the reductive carbonylation of NB under otherwise identical conditions. However, these are found to be mostly inactive neither for the conversion of NB nor for the yield of MPC (entry 3 and 4). To investigate the possible role of metal cation, various MSe2 (M = Mn, Co, Ni, Zn) were tested (entry 5∼8). However, these catalysts showed very poor activities toward MPC. From these result, it can be tentatively concluded that Se2 2− (Se-1) is most pivotal species responsible for high activity for MPC, and this trend is highly pronounced with the presence of cupric diselenide (CuIISe2). 3.4 Catalytic activities of CuSe2/CeO2 and characterization To improve the catalytic activity of the neat CuSe2, a wet impregnation method was employed using various supporting materials such as CeO2, γ-Al2O3, FAPO4, and activated carbon (AC) for 5 wt% of CuSe2 loading. Among them, as listed in Table 2, CeO2-supported CuSe2 shows the highest activity for MPC (96.4% yield, entry 10). The molar ratio of NB/CuSe2 in this reaction using 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2 is ten-times higher than the neat catalyst (CuSe2), suggesting that the catalytic activity of ceria-supported CuSe2 became improved. As expected, the MPC yield in the presence of neat CuSe2 at the molar ratio of 44 is very poor (6.0% yield, entry 9). Other types of supported systems are summarized in the Supporting Information (Table S-2), and XRD patterns of CuSe2/CeO2 and their XPS analysis data are also provided therein (Figs. S-4 and S-5). To investigate the morphologies of the catalysts synthesized either with or without CTAB, SEM analysis was performed. As shown in Fig. 3 , CuSe2 prepared without CTAB shows the irregular bar-type aggregated structures while CuSe2 synthesized with CTAB shows the uniformed flake type and highly dispersed structures. The size of CuSe2 without CTAB is found to be in the range of 2–5 μm (Fig. 3a and 3b), while the average size of CuSe2 synthesized with CTAB becomes reduced to ca. 400–500 nm (Fig. 3c and d). The catalytic activities are also correlated with the particle size, i.e., smaller in the size, the better activity in the reductive carbonylation. Fig. 3e and f show the SEM images of the CuSe2/CeO2 prepared without CTAB, which shows irregular rod and bar type structures. On the other hand, CuSe2/CeO2 prepared with CTAB shows uniformed and highly dispersed particle with the size range of 100–200 nm, which corresponds two times smaller than that from the neat CuSe2 prepared with CTAB. These results imply that the existence of CTAB results in a positive effect in rendering particle size of CuSe2 uniformed and smaller and these trends are more enhanced on the support material, CeO2, which in turn, leads to enhanced catalytic activity in the heterogeneous catalyst system. The results might be ascribed to the better dispersion of CuSe2 particles over ceria support during reduction process. Indeed, the yield of MPC using CuSe2/CeO2 prepared with the presence of CTAB is higher than that of without in the reductive carbonylation of NB (entry 3 and 4 in Table 3 ). TEM and EDS mapping images of CuSe2/CeO2 are provided in Fig. S-6. 3.5 Influence of reaction parameters on catalytic activity To monitor the product compositional changes as a function of time in the CuSe2/CeO2-catalyzed reductive carbonylation of NB (10 mmol), a series of reaction was performed by varying the reaction time from 0.5 h to 6.0 h. As shown in Fig. 4 , the amount of MPC formation increases with increasing reaction time until 4 h, and thereafter it remains constant. Accordingly, the amount of NB decreases very sharply with increasing time until 4 h. The formation of AN, the only by-product of this reaction, is successfully suppressed within 0.4 mmol (0.4 mol%) level throughout the reaction time with this catalyst, and other side-products were not detected by GC–MS except for very small amount of dimethyl carbonate (DMC). The effect of temperature on the reductive carbonylation of NB was examined using CuSe2/CeO2 as the catalyst at a temperature range of 120–180 °C under otherwise identical conditions. As can be seen in Fig. 5 , the yield of MPC increases with the temperature rise up to 160 °C, and then remains almost constant up to 180 °C. It is found that the formation of aniline cannot be neglected to some extent at a lower temperature ranges until 140 °C, however it decreases with the further increase in the temperature to suppress the formation of aniline formation and affords MPC in high yields. These results suggest that the CuSe2/CeO2 produces MPC in a highly selective fashion at higher temperature than 160 °C. A comparatively high amount of aniline formation at a low reaction temperature in the range of 120–140 °C might be due to the simple reduction of NB to AN other than carbonylation at these low temperature ranges. To study the influence of CO pressure on the activity, the reductive carbonylation were carried out at a varying pressure range of 4.1–9.5 MPa under otherwise identical conditions. The results in Fig. 6 show that the effect of pressure is not pronounced as much as the temperature, but at least 6.8 MPa of pressure is required to get a reasonable yield of MPC. To broaden the scope of the reductive carbonylation, various nitroarenes were tested for the formation of corresponding carbamates using CuSe2/CeO2 as the catalyst at 160 °C under 8.3 MPa of CO pressure for 4 h (hereafter it is referred to as standard conditions). The results summarized in Table 4 show that 1-methoxy-4-nitrobenzene bearing electron donor group (EDG) at para position is converted to the corresponding carbamate in excellent yield of 98.1% (entry 1) whereas 1-methyl-4-nitrobenzene bearing less EDG are carbonylated to produce the corresponding carbamates in lower yield (56.3%) than in the case of 1-methoxy-4-nitrobenzene (entry 2). When performed with 1-acetyl-4-nitrobenzene and 1-bromo-4-nitrobenzene bearing electron withdrawing groups (EWG) at para position, the yields of the carbamates are far reduced to 50.5% and 19.6%, respectively (entry 3 and 4). These results imply that the reductive carbonylation of the nitroarenes are largely influenced by EDG/EWG ability of the substituents, i.e., the more EDG at the para position favors carbonylation reaction. The 2,4-dinitrotoluene, an important raw material for producing toluene diisocyanate (TDI), is carbonylated, however, relatively lesser degree to give an only 40.2% yield of the corresponding dicarbamate even at the higher catalyst loading (molar ratio of sub/cat = 22), higher reaction temperature (180 °C), and longer reaction time (6 h) (entry 5). Interestingly, the reductive carbonylation of 1,4-nitroaniline produces 89.5% of the corresponding dicarbamate under the standard conditions, which is somewhat an unexpected result. Being motivated by this result, a series of reductive carbonylation was carried out by adding aniline (AN) with increasing molar ratio from 20% to 160% with respect to NB. As the results illustrated in Fig. 7 , the MPC yield increases with increasing molar ratio of AN up to 140% (substrate: NB 10 mmol and AN 14 mmol), and thereafter a sharp decrease is observed. The maximum yield of MPC is found to be 192% based on NB, which corresponds to 2 times higher than that in the absence of AN. The addition of an equimolar amount of AN with respect to NB has been previously reported to accelerate the rate of the reaction with a palladium-phenanthroline catalyst [19], moreover, in the presence of such an high amount of aniline, the selectivity of the reaction is much decreased and large amounts of azoxybenzene were formed [9]. However, the CuSe2/CeO2 protocol did not produce any azoxybenzene as side-product and thus nor decrease in the yield and/or selectivity to MPC. The reason for the additional formation of MPC is likely due to the following in-situ cascade reaction: 1) a reaction of aniline with an isocyanato intermediate leads to diphenyl urea (DPU), and 2) subsequent reaction of DPU with methanol allows MPC (see 3.7. Mechanistic consideration). This is quite reasonable because a quantitative formation of MPC is, in fact, possible from the reaction of DPU and methanol without a catalyst. It is worth noting that the MPC was not observed in the carbonylation of aniline as a sole substrate (entry 10, Table 4), suggesting that the aniline itself neither can be carbonylated, nor can act as an intermediate for MPC in the CuSe2-catalyzed reductive carbonylation. However, it could act as a reactant for the formation of DPU by reacting with an isocyanato species, which could be the reason for high reactivity of nitroaniline towards the reductive carbonylation (entry 6, Table 4). To verify this observation, dual substrates system comprising –nitro (10 mmol) and –amino (10 mmol) compound having the same functional group at the 4-position in the benzene ring were tested in the reductive carbonylation using 1 g of 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2 (molar ratio of sub/cat = 88) under otherwise identical conditions to the standard. Surprisingly, the corresponding carbamates were produced in 169.4 and 153.0% yields, respectively based on nitro compound (entries 7 and 8, Table 4), which corresponds to 1.8 and 1.7 times higher monocarbamate production compared to that using single substrate system. Prompted by these results, 2,4-dinitrotoluene and 2,4-diaminotoluene were tested as dual substrate in the reductive carbonylation using only 1 g of CuSe2/CeO2 (molar ratio of sub/cat = 88) under otherwise identical conditions, and surprisingly, the yield of dicarbamate was found to be as much as 80.7% (entry 9, Table 4). When considering the result obtained from single substrate system (40.2%) even at a higher temperature (180 °C), lower catalyst loading (molar ratio of sub/CuSe2 = 22), and longer reaction time (6 h), the result from the dual substrate system can be regarded as encouraging. 3.6 Catalyst recyclability To examine the recyclability of CuSe2/CeO2, a series of reductive carbonylation of NB was performed at milder conditions, i.e., 140 °C (original temperature: 160 °C) to exclude the high temperature effect that could result in constant high yield of MPC in evey run of recycling. After a reaction for 4 h, the liquid product mixture was removed by filtration using a cannula filter, and the remaining solid CuSe2/CeO2 was washed and dried under vacuum for 12 h, and reused for next reactions with a fresh charge of NB. As shown in Fig. 8 , CuSe2/CeO2 retains most of its original activity even after four runs, suggesting that this cheap heterogeneous catalyst is highly recyclable. Moreover, XRD analysis on the spent catalyst illustrated in Fig. 9 shows that the peaks retained its original 2θ and intensity, clearly indicating that the morphology and phase of this catalyst are not changed after the reaction. The SEM images of spent catalyst also reveal that there are no noticeable changes in their morphology when compared with a fresh one (Fig. S-18). To investigate possible changes in the oxidation state of the spent catalyst, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study was carried out. As can be confirmed in Fig. S-19, the spent catalyst reveals a small shift in Se 3d region from 54.77 to 55.1 eV. This result indicates a partial formation of Se (0) species during the reductive carbonylation [39,42,45], which is well accordance with the existence of the carbonyl selenide (Se0-CO) species as confirmed by FT-IR experiment (see Fig. 10 ). Whereas the oxidation the state of Cu did not change. These observations will be discussed more in the next section (3.7. Mechanistic consideration). To investigate possible leaching of selenium or cupper species, a solution obtained from the carbonylation reaction was analyzed with ICP-MS. Surprisingly, none of the leached species was detected, implying that CuSe2/CeO2 is a highly robust and heterogeneous catalyst in the reductive carbonylation. 3.7 Mechanistic consideration In order to find out active species in the CuSe2-catalyzed reductive carbonylation, CO chemisorption experiment was performed by reacting CuSe2 with 8.3 MPa of CO using methanol as a solvent in a pressurized reactor at 160 °C for 4 h, followed by drying the resulting solid under reduced pressure, and the solid was pelletized with KBr. However, no peak related to carbonylated CuSe2 is obtained from these methods (Fig. 10a). Interestingly, when the same is prepared in the presence of O2 together with CO, i.e., CO/O2 gas mixture (v/v = 80:20), FT-IR spectrum of this sample clearly shows a carbonyl peak at 1796 cm−1 (Fig. 10b). Since CO is not apt to bind Cu(II, d9), the formation of carbonyl moiety bound to Se(0) in the CuSe2 is a strong indication that i) the CO binds through the selenium species, and ii) the reaction of CO with CuSe2 to make carbonylated CuSe2 takes place only when Se1− is oxidized to Se(0) assisted by the oxidant. In the reductive carbonylation of NB catalyzed by CuSe2, NB is always playing an oxidant role. Indeed, when a sample is prepared in the presence of nitrobenzene (1 equiv. to CuSe2) as an oxidant under CO pressure without oxygen, FT-IR spectrum shows again the carbonyl peak at the same position (Fig. 10c). These results imply that one of the selenium species (Se-) in CuSe2 is likely to be oxidized to pseudo Se(0) species, which in turn, leads to a partial formation of carbonyl selenide (Se-CO) species. When considering the fact that the chemistry of carbonyl selenide has hardly been studied in contrast to carbonyl sulfide [38], and that the preparation of terminal carbonyl selenide requires harsh conditions such as reaction of elemental selenium with CO at 500–700 °C [46] or phosgenation with aluminum selenide at 210 °C [47], the detection of carbonyl selenide using CuSe2 seems to be very encouraging. In fact, the carbonyl selenide (Se-CO) synthesized from a modified methodology reported by Sonoda et al. was found to be a vapor phase at room temperature. Hence the pure Se-CO should have been obtained from distillation at – 50 °C/5 torr, and cooling at – 196 °C by adding ammonium selenocarbamate to the THF solution containing strong acid at – 78 °C [38]. When considering those facts, it is likely that the carbonyl peak observed at 1796 cm-1 in our FT-IR experiment should be assigned as bridging form. This can be supported by the another fact that the FT-IR stretching frequency of the terminal Se-CO as a vapor phase was around 2009 cm-1 [48], and that the CO stretching frequency in the FT-IR spectrum falls to 1720 – 1850 cm-1 on bridging [49]. Thus assigning the carbonyl peak at 1796 cm-1 as bridging form might be reasonable without difficulty. Despite the many pieces of evidence about the formation of carbonyl group bound to selenium, a relatively small intensity of carbonyl stretching frequency obtained from FT-IR led us to investigate Temperature Programmed Oxidation (TPO) on the fresh and spent catalyst (CuSe2/CeO2) to see CO2 formation arising from CO oxidation using 10% O2/H2 gas. The TPO results (Fig. S-29) show that the distinctive CO2 peak (m/z = 44) has been formed when spent catalyst was used as a sample, whereas the fresh catalyst did not show any CO2 peak. The appearance of CO2 peak from the spent catalyst might be resulted from the existence of [Se-CO] species, which has been generated from the reductive carbonylation of NB. Furthermore, this result is well consistent with the FT-IR experiments (Fig. 10). Based on the discussion mentioned above, a plausible reaction mechanism for the reductive carbonylation of NB in the presence of CuSe2 is suggested in Scheme 1 . The first step of the carbonylation would be a formation of an active catalyst from the reaction of CuSe2 with methanol to generate (MeO)2CuII(SeH)2 (1a) (Eq. 6), subsequent reaction of 1a with NB and CO to generate an active catalyst, CuSe2(μ-CO) (1b). It is worth mentioning again that the 1b cannot be formed by direct reaction of CuSe2 with CO (Eq. 5). As mentioned earlier, this reaction needs an oxidant such as oxygen or NB, which has been confirmed by FT-IR studies (Fig. 10). The combination of Eq. 6 and 7 produces Eq. 8, which indicates that the CuSe2(μ-CO) (1b) can be generated in the same conditions where the reductive carbonylation of NB is carried out. Although the efforts to detect 1a by reacting heterogeneous CuSe2 with methanol even at prolonged reaction time was not successful, the detection of aniline and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) was successful using GCMS by performing Eq. 8 with an equimolar amount NB, MeOH, CO, and CuSe2 (Supporting Information, S-8). Meanwhile, the Cu might play a certain role in facilitating the formation of 1a, and this is why other metals did not catalyze well in the reductive carbonylation of NB (Entries 5–8, Table 2). The neutral (SeH)2 moiety in 1a can be justified by the fact that the oxidation state of CuSe2 can be described as CuII(Se−)2. Cotton studied the semi-bridging carbonyl where the CO is neither fully terminal nor fully bridging, but intermediate between the two, and this is one of the many cases in organometallic chemistry [50]. The proposed structure of CuSe2(μ-CO) (1b) is also described as semi-bridging CO where the μ-CO is bound asymmetrically to two Se. Accordingly, the bond length of Se(δ2-)–CO is likely to be longer than that of Se0–CO, leading to easy insertion of NB between Se and carbonyl carbon, i.e., through the weaker interaction between them (vide infra). Once produced, the active catalyst, 1b may start to react with NB to generate 2b through the weaker bond interaction, which is in turn, decarboxylated to produce 3b. One molecule of CO would be inserted between Se and O in 3b to form 4b, another decarboxylation to generate a cupric diselenide nitrido species, 5b. The generation of 5b in this catalytic cycle in the reductive carbonylation of nitro compounds is of great importance just like the case of the generation of LnM = NR in the noble metal-catalyzed reductive carbonylation because it can easily be transformed into various products such as isocyanates, amines, ureas, and urethanes [4,11,14,16]. Accordingly, when the 5b interacts with another molecule of CO, then an isocyanato moiety, 6b would be generated. Finally, 6b may interact with methanol to produce one molecule of urethane with a concomitant generation of 1b. The reason for the dramatic increase in the urethane yields by adding the corresponding amino to the nitro compound can be rationalized as follows: i) 6b would react with amino compound (RNH2) to form dialkyl urea ((RNH)2CO), ii) which in turn, reacts with methanol to produce urethane and amine (alcoholysis process), iii) The generated amino compound subsequently participates in this small cycle repeatedly, leading to additional production of urethanes very effectively using this dual substrate system, which is emphasized as a solid box in Scheme 1. Therefore, the existence of the corresponding amino compound plays a critical role in facilitating CuSe2-catalyzed reductive carbonylation of NB, however, when using single substrate system (NB alone as substrate), an in-situ generated aniline during the formation of active catalyst (1b, in Scheme 1) might play a similar role as this case. 4 Conclusions Reductive carbonylation of nitrobenzene using a catalyst system comprising CuCl2, SeO2, and CTAB showed an excellent yield of MPC, and this catalyst component was found to be spontaneously transformed into a heterogeneous cupric diselenide, CuIISe2 during the carbonylation reaction. The pure CuSe2 was synthesized and successfully loaded onto CeO2 as a support material to produce a 5 wt% CuSe2/CeO2, which showed increased activity in the reductive carbonylation of NB. The formation of MPC under the catalytic influence of CuSe2/CeO2 was strongly dependent on both the temperature and reaction time: yield increased with increasing temperature and reaction time. The reactivities of various nitroarenes toward the reductive carbonylation reaction were largely influenced by the substituent at the para position of the nitrobenzene ring, i.e., more yields upon the larger electron donating ability. The CuSe2/CeO2 was found to be recycled up to four times without significant loss of its original activity. From the FT-IR study using CuSe2, it is likely to be transformed into asymmetric semi-bridging carbonyl diselenide, CuSe2(μ-CO) (1b) during the carbonylation, thereby facilitating insertion of NB to render this catalytic cycle affordable, and finally to regenerate 1b. Furthermore, the CuSe2/CeO2–catalyzed reductive carbonylation using a dual substrate system consisting of nitro- and its corresponding amino-compound produces far higher yields of monocarbamates as well as dicarbamate. The advantageous features of using this CuSe2/CeO2 catalyst includes that non-expensive and easy-to-prepare, which can be applied to the reductive carbonylation of various nitroarenes that had to employ precious noble metals such as Pd, Rh, and Ru to date. coredata.dc:description: The reaction of CuCl2, SeO2, and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) under the CO pressure in methanol produce a black solid, which is identified as cupric diselenide, CuIISe2 using various spectroscopic analyses. Impregnation of 5 wt% of CuSe2 onto CeO2 resulted in much more enhanced catalytic activity due to the uniform and highly dispersed particle. The reductive carbonylation of nitrobenzene (NB) as a model substrate has been examined in the presence of the CuSe2/CeO2 as a single component heterogeneous catalyst, which is found to exhibit excellent catalytic activity for generating methyl-N-phenyl carbamate (MPC) in a highly selective fashion. The effects of various reaction parameters such as temperature, pressure, and reaction time have been investigated. A plausible reaction mechanism using this cheap heterogeneous catalyst is also presented, especially invoking the importance of CuSe2(μ-CO) species.
coredata.dc:title: CuSe2/CeO2 as a novel heterogeneous catalyst for reductive carbonylation of nitroarenes for generating urethanes
